Properly managed, the mass media can provide the people of our nation,
wherever they are, with direct participation in public happenings of vital sig¬
nificance; they can illuminate, can teach, and even inspire.
Public affairs should be viewed in depth historically as well as pro¬
spectively. Enlightenment includes: clarification of goals, trends to date,
analytic examination of factors that condition the past, projection of future
potentialities, and evaluation of alternative policies. In other words, we need a
contextual approach to understand our place in the passing stream of events.
This is the kind of approach which the educational radio and television
stations are making and will increasingly bring to consideration of public affairs.
Commercial broadcasting, with its compulsion to seek the largest possible
audience at all times, is entertainment oriented. There can be little or no cumu¬
lation from one program to the next, and little introduction of material adapted to
an educational experience. The purpose, rather, is recreational, and the mood
established is one of irresponsibility and unreality; such programming conditions
the public to develop an allergy for matters of serious or disturbing nature.
In educational broadcasting the aim is not at a universal audience, but
at selected audiences. The purpose is not to be soporific—but to stimulate, to
arouse, to Inform, The emphasis is upon realism, judgment, responsibility,
and the effect is cumulative.
Commercial broadcasting is so constituted that its purpose is to seek
profits for its stockholders; non-commercial broadcasting's sole purpose is
serving the common good.
This is not to say that commercial broadcasting does not do some excel¬
lent programming In the public service area, providing background information
and interpretative comment, as well as giving spot news. However, such fare
tends to be scheduled In times of crises when national attention is so focused
as to make public affairs coverage profitable or is in response to critical scrutiny
from the FCC.
Crisis coverage, however, is not sufficiently consistent to make for an
informed public judgment.

in the United States audience instruction is in irresponsibility as an incidental
